Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Reagents and Strategies for Catalytic Nucleophilic Fluorination
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemical Synthesis Program is supporting the research of Professor Abigail G. Doyle of Princeton University to invent new reagents and strategies for nucleophilic fluorination. The first objective of this research is to develop Lewis base-catalyzed hydrofluorinations using benzoyl fluoride as a latent fluoride source. The second objective is to design catalytic methods for the regio- and stereoselective synthesis of allylic and benzylic fluorides. The research is expected to facilitate the discovery and manufacture of pharmaceutical agents, agrochemicals, and functional materials by enabling the preparation of novel fluorinated building blocks using inexpensive and readily available fluoride sources. Knowledge accrued through these investigations should give way to a better understanding of the impact of aliphatic fluorine substitution in biomedical and basic research and afford new opportunities for reaction design.

Professor Doyle will also be initiating educational outreach projects that interweave research and teaching. The impact of the education plan will be to broaden participation in STEM fields, particularly by underrepresented minorities and women, through early engagement of these students in hands-on research activities. One program involves providing students from a Trenton-area community college that serves a diverse population, including underrepresented minorities and low-income students, the opportunity to pursue research as part of their honors chemistry curriculum in Professor Doyle's laboratory. Second, the student invited lecture series at Princeton will be expanded to include speakers from industry, primarily undergraduate institutions, and government agencies to expose students to more varied career opportunities in the STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this program was to discover reactions that form organofluorine compounds (molecules that contain C–F bonds) in a safe, selective, economical, and environmentally friendly manner. Many useful molecules are organofluorine compounds: the polymer Teflon, the fuel-cell membrane Nafion, and many useful pharmaceuticals (including Lipitor, Prozac, Flonase, and Celebrex). Fluorine imparts unique and useful properties on these molecules because it is the most electronegative, or electron-greedy, element in the periodic table. In drug design, in particular, molecules containing one or more fluorine atoms often are metabolized more slowly by our bodies, pass more easily through biological barriers, and bind more strongly to the target proteins.

To make a C–F bond, two forms of fluorine are available: F– (fluoride, found in drinking water) or F+. Fluoride is the ideal fluorine source in terms of cost, abundance, and practicality. However, F– does not react readily to form C–F bonds for a variety of reasons. With the support of the NSF, we have devised new reagents and catalyst strategies for mild and selective C–F bond formation with fluoride. We have also pursued investigations to understand the underlying mechanism of these reactions. The insights from these studies enabled us to identify novel fluorination reactions and improved catalytic methods. The chemistry has seen adoption by practitioners of medicinal and process chemistry.

An important application of nucleophilic fluorination methods is to the synthesis of imaging agents for positron emission tomography (PET). Positron emission tomography (PET) is a powerful non-invasive imaging technology used in the areas of medical diagnosis and clinical research, as well as drug discovery and development. The PET image is obtained by visualization of a molecular probe labeled with a positron-emitting radioisotope such as [18F]fluorine. Under this NSF grant, the Doyle laboratory was able to translate their methods for C–F bond formation to the incorporation of the non-natural isotope of fluorine, 18-F, into organic molecules. This research addressed the need for new PET imaging agents by establishing broadly-useful new methodologies for late-stage radiofluorination.

Students engaged in the research obtained valuable training, not only in the expertise of the PI’s laboratory but a range of settings. Students became acquainted with fluorination protocols and PET imaging as they developed new methods for radiosynthesis. A student learned about computational chemistry techniques by conducting a collaborative study with an internationally-recognized computational chemistry expert in Sweden. Numerous students learned about industrially-relevant problems and approaches from collaborations with companies. The opportunity to network with scientists of different nationalities and vocations also offered students the ability to sharpen their communication skills and inform their professional plans. This exposure to varied research experiences is advantageous to all students but particularly to underrepresented groups, where increased engagement can encourage young scientists to pursue research in STEM. During the course of the CAREER grant, our lab hosted underrepresented minority and disadvantaged students through various programs and of the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers engaged in the studies of this grant, over 50% were female. This grant also supported engagement of younger children in STEM as the PI’s entire research group designed and delivered active chemistry demonstrations in outreach events at a local museum. Another important initiative that the PI spearheaded in this granting period is the Student Invited Lecture series. The series allows students in the chemistry department to invite and host speakers from academia, industry, and other chemistry-related careers.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/06/2017
Modified by: Abigail G Doyle
